discussion.content: I'd say it's C as in B you only _enable that keychain to be used there for that neighbor_, but you have to actually _configure_ it in the global..

comments.content: I have to disagree ;) - One thing is "enabling" and other thing is "configuring" (The actual keychain setting)

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs_r3-9/routing/command/reference/rr39crs1book_chapter1.html#wp1800220457
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:router(config)# router bgp 140 
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:router(config-bgp)# neighbor 172.20.1.1 
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:router(config-bgp-nbr)# remote-as 1 
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:router(config-bgp-nbr)# keychain keychain_A

discussion.content:
Correct answer is B, BGP keychain is configured under nbr config modes

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/iosxr/ncs5500/bgp/63x/b-bgp-cg-ncs5500-63x/b-bgp-cg-ncs5500-63x_chapter_010.html#task_81A7295F447946F880AB22C5D647CFF8

Selected Answer: C
to config BGP keychain : 
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config)# key chain <keychain-name>
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config-keychain)# key <key-id>
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config-keychain-key)# key-string <key-string>
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config-keychain-key)# send-lifetime <start-time> <end-time>
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config-keychain-key)# accept-lifetime <start-time> <end-time>

to enable BGP keychain :
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config)# router bgp <asn>
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config-bgp)# neighbor <neighbor-ipv4/ipv6>
RP/0/RP0/CPU0:ios(config-bgp-nbr)# password keychain <keychain-name>

Selected Answer: B
B because they are asking for BGP ...

Selected Answer: C
Key chain is a General mode configuration applicable for other services, in the BGP mode we're enabling the keychain, which was preconfigured before

Selected Answer: C
I guess answer is "c": https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs-r6-4/system-security/configuration/guide/b-system-security-cg-crs-64x/b-system-security-cg-crs-64x_chapter_0100.pdf

Answer is C 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/xr12000/software/xr12k_r3-9/security/configuration/guide/sc39kcm.html#wp1074457

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs-r6-2/system-security/command/reference/b-system-security-cr-62x-crs/m-keychain-management-commands-asr9k-ncs6k-crs.html#wp2210940733

It is: B.
SUMMARY STEPS
 configure
 router bgp [as-number]
 neighbor [ip-address]
 remote-as [as-number]
 keychain [name]
 Use the [commit] or [end] command.

So, "Keychain Configuration" actually takes place from here:
key chain <keychain_name>
 key <key_id>
 accept-lifetime <start-time> <end-time>
 key-string <master-key>
 send-lifetime <start-time> <end-time>
 cryptographic-algorithm <algorithm>
 !

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/iosxr/ncs5500/bgp/63x/b-bgp-cg-ncs5500-63x/b-bgp-cg-ncs5500-63x_chapter_010.html#id_77358

B according to Cisco XR guide below:

configure
router bgp as-number
neighbor ip-address
remote-as as-number
keychain name

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/iosxr/ncs5500/bgp/63x/b-bgp-cg-ncs5500-63x/b-bgp-cg-ncs5500-63x_chapter_010.html#:~:text=override%20inherited%20values.-,SUMMARY%20STEPS,-configure

Selected Answer: B
I would say the answer is B.

In the global configuration mode you can create a keychain, which can be used for BGP but also for ISIS or OSPF. The question is asking specifically for a BGP keychain which can be configured under the BGP neighbor configuration mode. For this reason I would say B is a more specific answer
C is correct. It is the keychain, not bop password.

questions.question_text: Which CLI mode must be used to configure the BGP keychain in Cisco IOS XR Software?

A remote operation center is deploying a set of I-BGP and E-BGP connections for multiple IOS-XR platforms using the same template. The I-BGP sessions exchange prefixes with no apparent issues, but the E-BGP sessions do not exchange routes. What causes this issue?

choices.D: The next-hop-self command is not implemented on both E-BGP neighbors.
choices.B: The E-BGP neighbors are not allowed to exchange Information due to the customer platform's default policy.
choices.C: A PASS ALL policy has not been implemented for the I-BGP neighbors.
choices.A: The I-BGP neighbors are mistyped and HELLO packets cannot be exchanged successfully between routers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
External BGP (eBGP) neighbors must have an inbound and outbound policy configured. If no policy is configured, no routes are accepted from the neighbor, nor are any routes advertised to it. This added security measure ensures that routes cannot accidentally be accepted or advertised in the case of a configuration omission error.
This enforcement affects only eBGP neighbors (neighbors in a different autonomous system than this router). For internal BGP (iBGP) neighbors (neighbors in the same autonomous system), all routes are accepted or advertised if there is no policy.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/xr12000/software/xr12k_r3-9/routing/configuration/guide/xr12krc39_chapter1.html

Selected Answer: B
IOS-XR default setting is to drop eBGP announcements if not explicitely configured to do it.

Selected Answer: C
I think the correct asnwer is C

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Routers R1 and R2 are part of a large enterprise network. The two devices are running BGP to advertise routes between them. The R1 Gi0/1 interface, which is connected to R2. is configured with the next hop for all advertised prefixes’ IP addresses. A network engineer noticed that R2 is not receiving certain routes from R1, which is causing connectivity issues. The engineer confirmed that the R2 IP address is reachable, and R2 is not filtering routes. Which action must the engineer take on R1 to resolve the issue?

choices.B: Apply route-map DENY_ROUTES under the BGP configuration.
choices.A: Add set metric 100 to the DENY_ROUTES route map.
choices.C: Remove sequence 10 from the BLOCKED_ROUTES prefix list.
choices.D: Change the sequence 10 action in the DENY_ROUTES route map to block.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is securing a customer's network. Which command must the engineer use to complete this configuration to prevent a DoS attack?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
RP/0/0/CPU0:R1(config)#router bgp 65534
RP/0/0/CPU0:R1(config-bgp)#neighbor 192.168.223.7
RP/0/0/CPU0:R1(config-bgp-nbr)#remote-as 65507
RP/0/0/CPU0:R1(config-bgp-nbr)#ttl-security ?
 inheritance-disable Prevent ttl-security from being inherited from the parent
 <cr>

D - ttl-security is the command on XR

There is no command "neighbor-ttl-security anyway

D is correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/asr9000/software/asr9k_r5-3/routing/command/reference/b-routing-cr53xasr9k/b-routing-cr53xasr9k_chapter_01.html#wp3198903688
D is coorect

It’s ios xr and D looks correct

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios_xr_sw/iosxr_r3-7/routing/command/reference/rr37bgp.html#wp2447776

comments.content:
I disagree, as stated in the other comments, the platform is IOS XR so we're already in 'neighbor' configuration mode, so we only need to enter the ttl-security configura
tion.

discussion.content: The correct answer should be A!!!

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A service provider is running MPLS in the core to support Layer 3 VPN. OSPF is configured to support dynamic routing, and BGP is enabled throughout the network. A network engineer is adding a new P router to the infrastructure and is connecting it to P1 and P3. Which task must the engineer perform on the new router to allow it to participate in the Layer 3 VPN?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Its P router not PE, so we dont need BGP enabled on that router as long as it learns labels to transport the traffic. A is correct for me.

choices.A: Establish an LDP neighbor relationship with P1 and P3.
choices.B: Enable LDP sync under the OSPF routing process.
choices.C: Enable LDP and establish an OSPF adjacency in a new area.
choices.D: Configure OSPF and BGP to support MPLS.
